mainEntity.name: How do I know if I'm a candidate for endoscopic spine surgery?

acceptedAnswer.text:
Candidates usually have leg-dominant pain from a herniated disc or lumbar stenosis that has not responded to six weeks of supervised physiotherapy and medication.
During consultation we review MRI scans, complete a focused neurological exam, and discuss work or sport demands before confirming the suitability of an endoscopic approach.

mainEntity.name: What recovery milestones should I expect after minimally invasive surgery?

acceptedAnswer.text:
Day 0: walk within three hours with physiotherapy support. Week 2: return to desk work once wound inspection is clear.
We schedule tele-follow ups at 48 hours, seven days, and 30 days, and the eight-week recovery roadmap below outlines each phase in detail.

mainEntity.name: How much does minimally invasive spine surgery cost with insurance?

acceptedAnswer.text:
Endoscopic discectomy packages typically range from INR 95,000 to 1,35,000 for self-pay patients including surgeon fees, OT charges, implants, and follow-up visits.
Cashless insurance approvals reduce out-of-pocket expense by roughly 12–18% once pre-authorisation is cleared. Contact us for a personalized quote based on your specific procedure and insurance coverage.

mainEntity.name: What documents do you provide for insurance or corporate approvals?

acceptedAnswer.text:
Our coordination team issues a detailed medical estimate, necessity letter, implant invoice, and operative summary aligned to TPA requirements.
Corporate employees also receive stamped medical leave summaries and fit-to-work certificates tailored to HR policies.

mainEntity.name: Do you offer teleconsultations for patients outside Hyderabad?

acceptedAnswer.text:
Yes. We provide secure video consultations for second opinions and post-operative reviews—share MRI scans via our encrypted portal or WhatsApp before the call.
International patients receive assistance with itinerary planning, visa documentation, and extended follow-up scheduling.

mainEntity.name: When can I travel or return to the gym after surgery?

acceptedAnswer.text:
Short domestic travel is generally safe after 7–10 days once pain is controlled and the wound has healed.
Gym and strength training resume after week six with progressive loading, while high-impact sports restart after clearance during the week-eight review.

mainEntity.name: How do you manage pain after endoscopic procedures?

acceptedAnswer.text:
We combine regional anaesthesia, targeted oral medication, and physiotherapy-led movement drills to keep discomfort below three on ten.
Patients receive breathing routines, cold-therapy guidance, and mindfulness resources with a 24/7 helpline for escalations.

mainEntity.name: Can I get a second opinion using my existing MRI scans?

acceptedAnswer.text:
Absolutely. Upload your DICOM files to our portal or bring the CD to clinic—we review images during consult and explain every treatment path in plain language.
You leave with a written care summary covering conservative care, surgical options, and red-flag symptoms that require urgent attention.

mainEntity.name: How quickly will I receive confirmation?

acceptedAnswer.text: Most appointment requests are confirmed within 30–60 minutes during clinic hours. We will contact you by phone or WhatsApp.

mainEntity.name: What documents should I bring?

acceptedAnswer.text: Please bring any MRI/CT scans, previous reports, and a list of current medications.

mainEntity.name: Can I reschedule after submitting?

acceptedAnswer.text: Yes. If you need to change the date or time, reply to the confirmation message or call the clinic.

mainEntity.name: Do you offer teleconsultations?

acceptedAnswer.text: Teleconsultations are available for follow-ups and initial triage. Choose the teleconsult option during scheduling.

mainEntity.name: Where is the clinic located?

acceptedAnswer.text: Dr. Sayuj Krishnan practices at Yashoda Hospitals, Malakpet, Hyderabad. The address is listed on the confirmation screen.

about.name: Endoscopic Spine Surgery
about.description: Minimally invasive spine procedures using advanced endoscopic techniques

about.name: Epilepsy Surgery
about.description: Comprehensive surgical treatment for drug-resistant epilepsy

mainEntity.name: What makes endoscopic surgery different from traditional surgery?

acceptedAnswer.text: Endoscopic surgery uses small incisions (8-10mm) and specialized instruments to access and treat spine conditions. This results in less muscle damage, reduced pain, faster recovery, and lower risk of complications compared to traditional open surgery.

mainEntity.name: How long is the recovery time for endoscopic procedures?

acceptedAnswer.text: Recovery times vary by procedure, but most endoscopic spine surgeries allow patients to return to desk work within 1-2 weeks and full activities within 4-6 weeks. This is significantly faster than traditional open surgery.

mainEntity.name: Are all patients candidates for minimally invasive surgery?

acceptedAnswer.text: Not all patients are suitable for endoscopic procedures. We evaluate each case individually based on MRI findings, symptoms, and overall health. Some complex cases may require traditional open surgery for optimal outcomes.

mainEntity.name: What should I expect during my consultation?

acceptedAnswer.text: During your consultation, Dr. Sayuj will review your MRI scans, discuss your symptoms, explain treatment options, and develop a personalized treatment plan. Bring your imaging studies and a list of current medications.

@graph.name: Best Neurosurgeon in Hyderabad | Dr. Sayuj Krishnan
@graph.description: Looking for the best neurosurgeon in Hyderabad? Dr. Sayuj Krishnan offers endoscopic spine surgery, brain tumor surgery, trigeminal neuralgia and epilepsy care. Safety-first, evidence-based treatment.

mainEntity.name: Is endoscopic always better than open surgery?

acceptedAnswer.text: No. We choose the approach that safely achieves full decompression for your anatomy and goals. Each case is evaluated individually to determine the safest and most effective technique.

mainEntity.name: Can I get a second opinion?

acceptedAnswer.text: Yes. Bring your MRI and reports; we'll review options and timelines. We encourage informed decision-making and are happy to provide second opinions.

mainEntity.name: Are older patients candidates for MISS?

acceptedAnswer.text: Many are—with careful selection, medical optimization, and clear recovery planning. Age alone is not a barrier; overall health and specific condition determine candidacy.

mainEntity.name: How do I choose the best neurosurgeon in Hyderabad?

acceptedAnswer.text: Look for fellowship training, high endoscopic case volumes, navigation/ICU support, transparent outcomes, and clear recovery plans. Dr. Sayuj practices at Yashoda Hospital, Malakpet with these safeguards in place.

mainEntity.name: What does minimally invasive spine surgery cost in Hyderabad?

acceptedAnswer.text: Endoscopic discectomy packages are typically ₹95,000–1,35,000 including surgeon fees, OT, implants, and follow-ups. Cashless insurance approval often reduces out-of-pocket expenses by 12–18% once pre-authorization is cleared.

@graph.name: How to book a consultation with Dr. Sayuj in Hyderabad
@graph.description: Three quick steps to schedule an in-clinic or teleconsultation at Yashoda Hospital, Malakpet.

tool.name: Secure video or WhatsApp link for imaging review

step.name: Share imaging & symptoms
step.text: Upload MRI/CT and a short symptom summary to hellodr@drsayuj.info or WhatsApp to confirm eligibility for an endoscopic or conservative path.

step.name: Pick a same-week slot
step.text: Coordination team schedules the earliest clinic or video slot—often same-day for nerve pain—and starts insurance pre-authorization.

step.name: Visit Yashoda, Malakpet
step.text: Bring your ID, insurance card, and medication list. The final plan and recovery roadmap are shared in writing after consultation.

structuredData.description: Expert endoscopic discectomy for herniated discs in Hyderabad. Same-day surgery, faster recovery, less pain with Dr. Sayuj Krishnan.

isPartOf.name: Dr. Sayuj Krishnan - Neurosurgeon in Hyderabad

mainEntity.name: Endoscopic Discectomy
mainEntity.description: Expert endoscopic discectomy for herniated discs in Hyderabad. Same-day surgery, faster recovery, less pain with Dr. Sayuj Krishnan.

mainEntity.name: How long does endoscopic discectomy surgery take?

acceptedAnswer.text: Endoscopic discectomy typically takes 45-90 minutes depending on the complexity of the case. The procedure is performed under general anesthesia and uses a small endoscope to remove the herniated disc material through a tiny 8-10mm incision.

mainEntity.name: What is the recovery time after endoscopic discectomy?

acceptedAnswer.text: Most patients can return to desk work within 1-2 weeks after endoscopic discectomy. Physical jobs may require 4-8 weeks. The procedure allows for same-day or 1-night hospital stay, with most patients walking the same day. Full recovery typically takes 4-6 weeks.

mainEntity.name: Is endoscopic discectomy better than open surgery?

acceptedAnswer.text: Endoscopic discectomy offers several advantages over traditional open surgery: smaller incision (8-10mm vs 3-4cm), less muscle damage, reduced blood loss, lower infection risk, faster recovery, and same-day discharge. Success rates are comparable (85-90%) with less post-operative pain.

mainEntity.name: What are the risks of endoscopic discectomy?

acceptedAnswer.text: Endoscopic discectomy is generally safe with low complication rates. Potential risks include infection (<1%), nerve injury (<1%), dural tear (<2%), and recurrence (5-10%). Dr. Sayuj Krishnan's experience with 1000+ endoscopic procedures results in excellent safety outcomes.

mainEntity.name: Who is a good candidate for awake spine surgery?

acceptedAnswer.text: Patients with cardiac, pulmonary, or metabolic risks who should avoid prolonged general anaesthesia, elderly patients, and those needing short endoscopic decompressions or discectomy often benefit most.

mainEntity.name: What type of anaesthesia is used?

acceptedAnswer.text: We combine spinal or epidural anaesthesia with light conscious sedation. You breathe on your own, feel no pain, and we monitor comfort throughout the case.

mainEntity.name: Is recovery faster than conventional surgery?

acceptedAnswer.text: Yes. Awake endoscopic approaches use 6–8 mm incisions with minimal muscle disruption. Most patients sit up within hours and go home the same day or after one night of observation.

structuredData.description: Expert spinal fusion surgery (TLIF/PLIF) by Dr. Sayuj Krishnan. Stabilization for spondylolisthesis and fractures. Minimally invasive screw fixation.

mainEntity.name: Spinal Fusion Surgery
mainEntity.description: Expert spinal fusion surgery (TLIF/PLIF) by Dr. Sayuj Krishnan. Stabilization for spondylolisthesis and fractures. Minimally invasive screw fixation.

mainEntity.name: What is spinal fusion surgery?

acceptedAnswer.text: Spinal fusion is a surgery to permanently connect two or more vertebrae in your spine, eliminating motion between them. It uses screws, rods, and bone grafts to create a solid bridge of bone.

mainEntity.name: When is spinal fusion necessary?

acceptedAnswer.text: It is needed when the spine is unstable, such as in spondylolisthesis (slipped vertebra), fractures, severe arthritis, or after removing a large spinal tumor. Simple back pain rarely needs fusion.

mainEntity.name: Will I lose flexibility?

acceptedAnswer.text: Fusion limits motion only at the fused segment. Since most motion comes from the hip and cervical spine, fusing one or two lumbar levels typically does not noticeably restrict daily activities.

mainEntity.name: What is the success rate?

acceptedAnswer.text: For properly selected patients with instability, success rates are over 90%. Pain relief is significant once the fusion solidifies.

mainEntity.name: How long do implants stay in the body?

acceptedAnswer.text: The titanium screws and rods are designed to stay in your body permanently. They do not trigger metal detectors and rarely need removal unless there is an infection or discomfort.

mainEntity.name: What is the difference between Vertebroplasty and Kyphoplasty?

acceptedAnswer.text: Vertebroplasty involves injecting cement directly into the fractured bone to stabilize it. Kyphoplasty uses a balloon first to create a cavity and restore height before injecting cement. Kyphoplasty is better if there is significant height loss.

mainEntity.name: Is general anaesthesia required?

acceptedAnswer.text: Usually, no. Both procedures can be performed under local anaesthesia with mild sedation (Monitored Anaesthesia Care), making it safe for elderly patients with other health issues.

mainEntity.name: How quickly does the pain go away?

acceptedAnswer.text: Most patients experience significant pain relief within 2 to 24 hours after the procedure. The cement hardens in minutes, providing immediate stability.

mainEntity.name: Are these procedures safe for elderly patients?

acceptedAnswer.text: Yes, these are specifically designed for elderly patients with osteoporosis. Since they are minimally invasive and avoid general anaesthesia, they are very safe even for those 80+ years old.

mainEntity.name: Can I walk after surgery?

acceptedAnswer.text: Yes, we encourage patients to walk within 2-3 hours after the procedure. Early mobilization helps prevent complications like blood clots and pneumonia.

mainEntity.name: What is the cost of Vertebroplasty in Hyderabad?

acceptedAnswer.text: The cost typically ranges from ₹1.1 Lakh to ₹1.4 Lakh depending on the number of levels and type of cement used. Insurance usually covers this procedure.

structuredData.name: Peripheral Nerve Surgery in Hyderabad
structuredData.description: Expert peripheral nerve surgery including carpal tunnel release, ulnar nerve decompression, and nerve tumor removal in Hyderabad.

isPartOf.name: Dr. Sayuj Krishnan - Neurosurgeon in Hyderabad

mainEntity.name: Peripheral Nerve Surgery
mainEntity.description: Expert peripheral nerve surgery including carpal tunnel release, ulnar nerve decompression, and nerve tumor removal in Hyderabad.

mainEntity.name: Is endoscopic carpal tunnel release better than open surgery?

acceptedAnswer.text: Both techniques are effective, but endoscopic carpal tunnel release offers advantages including smaller incisions, less post-operative pain, faster recovery, and reduced scarring. However, open release may be preferred for complex cases or when additional procedures are needed.

mainEntity.name: How long does numbness take to improve after nerve decompression?

acceptedAnswer.text: Numbness improvement varies by individual and condition severity. Some patients notice improvement within days to weeks, while others may take 3-6 months for full recovery. Severe cases with long-standing compression may have permanent residual numbness.

mainEntity.name: Can nerve function fully recover after surgery?

acceptedAnswer.text: Recovery depends on several factors including the duration of compression, severity of damage, and patient age. Early intervention typically yields better outcomes. While many patients achieve significant improvement, complete recovery may not always be possible in severe cases.

mainEntity.name: Do I need EMG/NCS (nerve conduction studies) before surgery?

acceptedAnswer.text: Yes, EMG/NCS are essential for confirming the diagnosis, localizing the problem, and assessing severity. These tests help determine if surgery is indicated and provide baseline measurements for post-operative comparison.

mainEntity.name: Will insurance cover peripheral nerve decompression surgery?

acceptedAnswer.text: Most insurance plans cover peripheral nerve surgery when medically necessary. We work with all major insurance providers and TPAs to ensure coverage. Our team will help verify your benefits and handle pre-authorization if required.

mainEntity.name: What are the risks of peripheral nerve surgery?

acceptedAnswer.text: While generally safe, potential risks include infection, bleeding, nerve injury, incomplete relief, and recurrence. Dr. Sayuj uses microsurgical techniques, nerve monitoring, and careful patient selection to minimize these risks.

mainEntity.name: When should I consider surgery for carpal tunnel syndrome?

acceptedAnswer.text: Surgery is recommended when conservative treatments (splinting, injections, therapy) fail, symptoms are severe, or there is muscle wasting. Early surgical intervention often provides better outcomes than waiting for severe nerve damage.

mainEntity.name: How much does endoscopic spine surgery cost in Hyderabad?

acceptedAnswer.text: The cost of endoscopic spine surgery in Hyderabad typically ranges from ₹2,50,000 to ₹4,00,000 depending on the technique (TESS vs Interlaminar) and hospital category. This includes surgeon fees, theatre charges, and a 1-night hospital stay.

mainEntity.name: What is the cost of titanium spine implants?

acceptedAnswer.text: Spine implants (screws and rods) are charged separately. High-grade Indian titanium implants cost approx. ₹35,000–₹50,000 per level, while imported (US/German) FDA-approved implants range from ₹60,000–₹1,00,000 per level.

mainEntity.name: Is spine surgery covered by insurance in Hyderabad?

acceptedAnswer.text: Yes, nearly all comprehensive health insurance policies cover spine surgery (discectomy, fusion, laminectomy). We accept cashless claims from major providers like Star Health, HDFC Ergo, Niva Bupa, SBI General, and ICICI Lombard at Yashoda Hospital.

mainEntity.name: Why is endoscopic surgery cost higher than open surgery?

acceptedAnswer.text: Endoscopic surgery requires specialized disposable kits, high-definition cameras, and advanced burrs, which increases the consumable cost. However, the total cost often balances out due to shorter hospital stays (1 day vs 3-4 days) and faster return to work.

mainEntity.name: How much does slip disc surgery cost in Hyderabad?

acceptedAnswer.text: Slip disc (herniated disc) surgery costs in Hyderabad range from ₹2,50,000 to ₹4,00,000 for endoscopic discectomy, and ₹2,00,000 to ₹3,50,000 for traditional open discectomy. Endoscopic surgery offers better value with same-day discharge and faster recovery, despite slightly higher initial cost.

mainEntity.name: Is endoscopic discectomy more expensive than open surgery?

acceptedAnswer.text: Endoscopic discectomy typically costs ₹2,50,000-4,00,000 compared to ₹2,00,000-3,50,000 for open surgery. However, endoscopic surgery often results in lower overall costs due to same-day discharge, reduced medication needs, and faster return to work. The minimally invasive approach provides better value.

mainEntity.name: Does insurance cover slip disc surgery?

acceptedAnswer.text: Yes, most health insurance plans cover slip disc surgery including endoscopic discectomy. Cashless insurance options are available at Yashoda Hospital. Our team assists with pre-authorization and helps you understand your coverage. Contact us to verify your insurance eligibility.

structuredData.name: Slip Disc Treatment in Hyderabad | Endoscopic Discectomy
structuredData.description: Expert slip disc treatment in Hyderabad. From conservative care to endoscopic discectomy. Same-day discharge, minimal pain. Book consultation with Dr. Sayuj Krishnan.

isPartOf.name: Dr. Sayuj Krishnan - Neurosurgeon in Hyderabad

mainEntity.name: Slip Disc Treatment
mainEntity.description: Expert slip disc treatment in Hyderabad. From conservative care to endoscopic discectomy. Same-day discharge, minimal pain. Book consultation with Dr. Sayuj Krishnan.

mainEntity.name: What is a slip disc and how is it treated?

acceptedAnswer.text: A slip disc (herniated disc) occurs when the soft center of a spinal disc pushes through a crack in the outer ring. Treatment begins with conservative measures like medication and physiotherapy. If symptoms persist, Dr. Sayuj Krishnan specializes in endoscopic discectomy, a minimally invasive procedure for lasting relief.

mainEntity.name: Do I always need surgery for a slip disc?

acceptedAnswer.text: No. 80-90% of slip disc patients recover with conservative treatment (medications, rest, physiotherapy) within 6 weeks. Surgery is only recommended if there is severe pain, weakness, or no improvement after non-surgical care.

mainEntity.name: How long does endoscopic discectomy take?

acceptedAnswer.text: The endoscopic discectomy procedure typically takes 45-60 minutes. Most patients can walk the same day and return to desk work within 1-2 weeks. Physical jobs may require 4-8 weeks with a graded return plan.

mainEntity.name: What are the benefits of endoscopic discectomy over traditional surgery?

acceptedAnswer.text: Endoscopic discectomy offers several advantages: smaller incision (6-8mm vs 3-4 inches), less muscle damage, minimal blood loss, same-day discharge, faster recovery, and reduced risk of complications. The procedure preserves normal spinal anatomy while effectively treating the herniated disc.

mainEntity.name: Who is a candidate for endoscopic discectomy?

acceptedAnswer.text: Candidates include patients with leg-dominant pain from herniated discs who haven't improved with conservative treatment (medications, physiotherapy). Dr. Krishnan evaluates each case individually, considering MRI findings, symptoms, and overall health to determine the best treatment approach.

mainEntity.name: What is the success rate of endoscopic discectomy?

acceptedAnswer.text: Endoscopic discectomy has a high success rate of 85-95% for appropriate candidates. Success depends on proper patient selection, surgeon experience, and following post-operative care instructions. Dr. Krishnan's extensive experience in minimally invasive spine surgery ensures optimal outcomes.

structuredData.name: Sciatica Treatment in Hyderabad | Non-Surgical & Endoscopic Options
structuredData.description: Expert sciatica treatment in Hyderabad by Dr. Sayuj Krishnan. 90% of patients recover without surgery. Get a precise diagnosis and non-surgical relief plan.

isPartOf.name: Dr. Sayuj Krishnan - Neurosurgeon in Hyderabad

mainEntity.name: Sciatica Treatment
mainEntity.description: Expert sciatica treatment in Hyderabad by Dr. Sayuj Krishnan. 90% of patients recover without surgery. Get a precise diagnosis and non-surgical relief plan.

mainEntity.name: What is sciatica?

acceptedAnswer.text: Sciatica is not a condition itself, but a symptom of an underlying problem. It refers to pain that radiates along the path of the sciatic nerve, which branches from your lower back through your hips and buttocks and down each leg.

mainEntity.name: Can sciatica be cured without surgery?

acceptedAnswer.text: Yes. In fact, 90% of our patients recover completely with non-surgical methods like targeted nerve blocks, medication, and specialized physiotherapy. Surgery is a last resort, not the first step.

mainEntity.name: What causes sciatica?

acceptedAnswer.text: The most common cause is a herniated (slipped) disc compressing the nerve root. Other causes include spinal stenosis (narrowing of the spine), bone spurs, or rarely, a tumor or diabetic neuropathy.

mainEntity.name: Does sciatica always require surgery?

acceptedAnswer.text: No. 80-90% of sciatica cases resolve with conservative treatments like medication, physiotherapy, and rest. Surgery (endoscopic discectomy) is only recommended if pain persists after 6 weeks or if there is severe weakness.

mainEntity.name: How is sciatica diagnosed?

acceptedAnswer.text: Diagnosis starts with a physical exam to check muscle strength and reflexes (Straight Leg Raise test). An MRI scan is the gold standard to visualize the nerve compression and identify the exact cause.

mainEntity.name: What are the warning signs of severe sciatica?

acceptedAnswer.text: Seek immediate medical attention if you experience: sudden severe pain after an accident, loss of bowel/bladder control (Cauda Equina Syndrome), or progressive weakness/numbness in the leg.

mainEntity.name: What is the cost of sciatica treatment in Hyderabad?

acceptedAnswer.text: The cost depends on the procedure. A simple nerve root block may cost ₹15,000–₹25,000, while endoscopic spine surgery typically ranges from ₹1.5 Lakhs to ₹2.5 Lakhs depending on the hospital category and implant requirements.

mainEntity.name: Is my office chair causing my sciatica?

acceptedAnswer.text: Prolonged sitting is a major risk factor. Poor ergonomics can increase pressure on lumbar discs by 40%, potentially triggering or worsening sciatica. We recommend ergonomic adjustments and taking breaks every 30 minutes.

mainEntity.name: Is it Sciatica or Piriformis Syndrome?

acceptedAnswer.text: True sciatica comes from the spine (nerve root compression). Piriformis syndrome is when a muscle in the buttock compresses the sciatic nerve. Dr. Sayuj uses specific clinical tests to distinguish them, as treatments differ significantly (spine decompression vs. muscle release).

mainEntity.name: Is sciatica common during pregnancy?

acceptedAnswer.text: Yes, up to 50% of women experience some sciatic pain during pregnancy due to the baby's weight and postural changes. We offer safe, medication-free physiotherapy protocols to manage this pain without risking the baby's health.

mainEntity.name: Can I drive with sciatica?

acceptedAnswer.text: Driving often worsens sciatica due to the vibration and leg position. We recommend short trips, using a lumbar support cushion, and stopping every 30 minutes to stretch. If you have foot weakness (foot drop), do not drive.

mainEntity.name: What exercises should I avoid with sciatica?

acceptedAnswer.text: Avoid heavy hamstring stretches, straight leg raises, and twisting movements like golf until cleared by a physio. These can increase nerve tension.

mainEntity.name: What is lumbar canal stenosis?

acceptedAnswer.text: It is a narrowing of the spinal canal in the lower back. This narrowing squeezes the nerves that travel to your legs, causing pain, heaviness, or numbness when walking.

mainEntity.name: Why do my legs hurt only when I walk?

acceptedAnswer.text: This is called "Neurogenic Claudication". When you stand or walk, your spine arches slightly, narrowing the canal further and pinching the nerves. Sitting or bending forward opens the canal and relieves the pain.

mainEntity.name: Is surgery necessary for stenosis?

acceptedAnswer.text: Surgery is advised if your walking distance is significantly reduced (e.g., you can't walk more than 10 minutes) or if you have numbness/weakness. Mild cases can be managed with medication and exercises.

mainEntity.name: What is the success rate of stenosis surgery?

acceptedAnswer.text: Decompression surgery has a very high success rate (over 90%) for relieving leg pain and improving walking ability. Back pain relief varies depending on other factors.

mainEntity.name: How is Micro-Decompression different from Laminectomy?

acceptedAnswer.text: Micro-decompression uses a microscope and a smaller incision to remove only the bone spur pressing the nerve, preserving spinal stability. Traditional laminectomy removes more bone and muscle.

structuredData.name: Cervical Radiculopathy Treatment in Hyderabad
structuredData.description: Expert treatment for cervical radiculopathy (pinched nerve) in Hyderabad. Endoscopic keyhole surgery for arm pain, numbness, and neck pain by Dr. Sayuj Krishnan.

isPartOf.name: Dr. Sayuj Krishnan — Brain & Spine Clinic

about.name: Cervical Radiculopathy
signOrSymptom: Weakness in arm or hand muscles
Neck pain radiating to the shoulder blade
Relief when lifting the arm over the head

mainEntity.name: Does a pinched nerve in the neck require surgery?

acceptedAnswer.text: Not always. 90% of cervical radiculopathy cases improve with medication and physiotherapy within 6-8 weeks. Surgery is recommended if there is severe weakness, intractable pain, or if conservative treatment fails.

mainEntity.name: What is the best surgery for cervical radiculopathy?

acceptedAnswer.text: For pure nerve pinching without instability, a Minimally Invasive Posterior Cervical Foraminotomy (Keyhole Surgery) is excellent as it preserves motion and requires no fusion. For large central discs, ACDF or Disc Replacement may be better.

mainEntity.name: How long does it take to recover from pinched nerve surgery?

acceptedAnswer.text: Recovery is rapid. With endoscopic keyhole surgery, patients are often discharged the same day or next day. Desk work can resume in 1-2 weeks. Full return to sports takes about 6-12 weeks.

mainEntity.name: Do I really need surgery for spondylolisthesis?

acceptedAnswer.text: Not always. Surgery is usually recommended only if you have Grade 3/4 slips, or if you have Grade 1/2 slips with persistent nerve pain/weakness that hasn't improved after 6 weeks of rehabilitation and medication.

mainEntity.name: What is the cost of spondylolisthesis surgery in Hyderabad?

acceptedAnswer.text: The cost typically ranges from ₹2.5 Lakhs to ₹3.5 Lakhs for Minimally Invasive TLIF (Fusion). This includes hospital stay, implants, and surgeon fees. Open surgery may cost slightly less, but recovery is longer.

mainEntity.name: How long is the recovery after spinal fusion?

acceptedAnswer.text: With MIS-TLIF, patients usually walk the next day. Desk work can often resume in 3-4 weeks. Complete bone fusion takes 3-6 months, during which heavy lifting is restricted.

mainEntity.name: Can spondylolisthesis be cured with exercise?

acceptedAnswer.text: Grade 1 slips can often be stabilized with core strengthening exercises. While the slip itself won't reverse, the pain can vanish completely, avoiding the need for surgery.

mainEntity.name: Is MIS TLIF better than open surgery?

acceptedAnswer.text: Yes, for most patients. MIS TLIF involves smaller incisions, less muscle cutting, less blood loss, and a shorter hospital stay compared to traditional open fusion.

mainEntity.name: Does every scoliosis patient need surgery?

acceptedAnswer.text: No. Surgery is only recommended for curves greater than 40-50 degrees that are progressing or causing lung/heart issues. Mild curves are managed with observation and bracing.

mainEntity.name: What is the cost of scoliosis surgery in Hyderabad?

acceptedAnswer.text: Complex scoliosis correction typically ranges from ₹4 Lakhs to ₹6 Lakhs depending on the number of levels fused and the type of implants used. This includes IONM (nerve monitoring) for safety.

mainEntity.name: Can scoliosis be corrected in adults?

acceptedAnswer.text: Yes. While it is often treated in adolescents, adult degenerative scoliosis can also be corrected surgically to relieve pain and improve posture.

mainEntity.name: How long is the recovery after scoliosis surgery?

acceptedAnswer.text: Patients usually walk within 2-3 days. Return to school/desk work takes 4-6 weeks. Full bone fusion and return to sports may take 6-12 months.

mainEntity.name: Is the surgery safe?

acceptedAnswer.text: Modern scoliosis surgery uses Neuromonitoring (IONM) to monitor nerve function in real-time during the operation, significantly increasing safety and reducing risks.

structuredData.name: Brain Tumor Surgery in Hyderabad
structuredData.description: Detailed guidance on brain tumour diagnosis, microsurgery, radiosurgery, and recovery with Dr. Sayuj Krishnan at Yashoda Hospital, Malakpet.

isPartOf.name: Dr. Sayuj Krishnan — Brain & Spine Clinic

mainEntity.name: Is brain tumour surgery always necessary?

acceptedAnswer.text: Surgery is advised when the benefits outweigh risks, such as relieving pressure or obtaining diagnosis. Some benign tumours can be monitored with routine imaging.

mainEntity.name: Will I need radiation after surgery?

acceptedAnswer.text: High-grade tumours often need adjuvant radiotherapy or chemotherapy. Benign tumours may not require further treatment if fully removed.

mainEntity.name: How safe is awake craniotomy?

acceptedAnswer.text: Awake craniotomy is carefully planned with anaesthetists and neuropsychologists to preserve speech or motor function. Complications are rare with experienced teams.

@graph.name: Brain Aneurysm
@graph.description: Emergency evaluation and microsurgical or endovascular strategies for ruptured and unruptured aneurysms.

signOrSymptom.name: Sudden severe headache often described as thunderclap
Vision changes, neck stiffness, or loss of consciousness

possibleTreatment.name: Emergency stabilisation and blood pressure control

mainEntity.name: When should an unruptured aneurysm be treated?

acceptedAnswer.text: Size, location, and patient factors determine timing. Symptomatic or enlarging aneurysms require early intervention after multidisciplinary review.

mainEntity.name: What follow-up imaging is needed?

acceptedAnswer.text: Post-treatment MR or CT angiography at 6 and 12 months ensures the aneurysm remains sealed and detects recurrence early.

structuredData.name: Trigeminal Neuralgia Treatment in Hyderabad
structuredData.description: Explore medicines, microvascular decompression, radiosurgery and percutaneous options for trigeminal neuralgia in Hyderabad with Dr. Sayuj Krishnan.

isPartOf.name: Dr. Sayuj Krishnan - Neurosurgeon in Hyderabad

mainEntity.name: Trigeminal Neuralgia
mainEntity.description: Explore medicines, microvascular decompression, radiosurgery and percutaneous options for trigeminal neuralgia in Hyderabad with Dr. Sayuj Krishnan.

mainEntity.name: Is trigeminal neuralgia curable?

acceptedAnswer.text: Many patients achieve sustained pain relief with procedures such as microvascular decompression or radiosurgery. Recurrence can happen, so structured follow-up remains important.

mainEntity.name: How long does Gamma Knife radiosurgery take to work?

acceptedAnswer.text: Relief is gradual. Most people notice improvement two to eight weeks after treatment, and medicines are tapered only when symptoms remain controlled.

mainEntity.name: What are the risks of MVD?

acceptedAnswer.text: Serious complications are uncommon, particularly with neuromonitoring. Potential risks include hearing changes, facial numbness, or cerebrospinal fluid leak, all discussed before surgery.

mainEntity.name: Can trigeminal neuralgia return after treatment?

acceptedAnswer.text: Yes, especially years later. Recurrence does not rule out further treatment—repeat MVD, radiosurgery, or percutaneous options can still help.

mainEntity.name: Is medication enough for everyone?

acceptedAnswer.text: Medicines control pain for many people, but side effects or breakthrough pain may prompt procedures. We decide together based on symptom control and MRI findings.

structuredData.name: Signs of a Brain Tumor
structuredData.description: Identify early warning signs of brain tumours, emergency red flags, and diagnostic steps available in Hyderabad with Dr. Sayuj Krishnan.

isPartOf.name: Dr. Sayuj Krishnan — Brain & Spine Clinic

mainEntity.name: Are all persistent headaches caused by brain tumours?

acceptedAnswer.text: Most headaches are caused by benign conditions such as migraine or tension. Seek specialist evaluation when headaches worsen, occur with neurological symptoms, or feel different from your usual pattern.

mainEntity.name: When should I get an MRI for headache or neurological symptoms?

acceptedAnswer.text: An MRI is recommended when headaches are progressive, accompanied by seizures, vision changes, or neurological deficits. Your neurosurgeon will advise the specific protocol.

mainEntity.name: Can lifestyle changes reverse brain tumour symptoms?

acceptedAnswer.text: Lifestyle modifications support overall health but do not treat tumours. Early medical assessment ensures appropriate imaging and treatment planning.

structuredData.name: Pain on Top of Head Causes
structuredData.description: Learn common and serious causes of vertex headaches, red flags, and treatment options available in Hyderabad with Dr. Sayuj Krishnan.

isPartOf.name: Dr. Sayuj Krishnan — Brain & Spine Clinic

about.name: Headache
signOrSymptom: Pain on the crown of the head

mainEntity.name: Is pain on the top of my head always serious?

acceptedAnswer.text: Most cases relate to tension or posture. Seek medical care when pain is severe, persistent, or accompanied by neurological symptoms.

mainEntity.name: Can cervical spine problems cause vertex headaches?

acceptedAnswer.text: Yes. Cervical radiculopathy and facet arthropathy frequently refer pain to the top of the head. Imaging and examination confirm the diagnosis.

mainEntity.name: Do I need an MRI for head pain?

acceptedAnswer.text: MRI is recommended when headaches persist despite treatment, present with red flags, or occur alongside neurological deficits. Your specialist will advise based on symptoms.

itemListElement.name: Leg Pain While Walking: Is it Spinal Stenosis or Poor Circulation? (PAD)

@graph.headline: Leg Pain While Walking: Is it Spinal Stenosis or Poor Circulation? (PAD)
@graph.description: Confused by leg pain while walking? Learn the difference between Spinal Stenosis and PAD (Circulation) and when to see a neurosurgeon.

mainEntity.name: Why does my leg pain go away when I sit?

acceptedAnswer.text: If sitting relieves your pain quickly, it's likely Spinal Stenosis. Sitting flexes the spine and opens the spinal canal, relieving pressure on the nerves. If the pain takes a long time to go away even after stopping, it might be poor circulation (PAD).

mainEntity.name: Can I have both Spinal Stenosis and PAD?

acceptedAnswer.text: Yes, unfortunately. Both conditions are common in people over 60, especially smokers or diabetics. A thorough evaluation with both MRI (for spine) and Doppler ultrasound (for blood flow) is needed.

mainEntity.name: What is the 'Bicycle Test'?

acceptedAnswer.text: It's a simple way to distinguish the two. If you can ride a stationary bike without pain but can't walk, it's likely Spinal Stenosis (because you are leaning forward). If you get pain on the bike too, it could be PAD (because muscles need blood regardless of posture).

mainEntity.name: Which doctor should I see for leg pain when walking?

acceptedAnswer.text: Start with a spine specialist if your pain improves with bending forward. If you have cold feet or weak pulses, see a vascular surgeon. Our clinic can help diagnose the root cause.

itemListElement.name: Is Spine Surgery Safe? Understanding Risks and Success Rates in Hyderabad

@graph.headline: Is Spine Surgery Safe? Understanding Risks and Success Rates in Hyderabad
@graph.description: Is spine surgery safe? Explore the truth about paralysis risks, success rates (90%+), and how modern endoscopic techniques in Hyderabad have changed the game.

mainEntity.name: What are the chances of paralysis after spine surgery?

acceptedAnswer.text: Extremely low. With modern microscopic and endoscopic techniques used in Hyderabad, the risk of serious nerve damage causing paralysis is typically less than 0.5% for routine surgeries like discectomies.

mainEntity.name: How successful is spine surgery?

acceptedAnswer.text: Success rates for conditions like herniated discs (sciatica) are generally over 90-95% when the patient is correctly selected. Endoscopic spine surgery offers similar success rates with faster recovery.

mainEntity.name: Is spine surgery painful?

acceptedAnswer.text: Modern anesthesia and minimally invasive techniques significantly reduce post-operative pain. Most endoscopic patients report immediate relief from leg pain and only mild soreness at the incision site.

mainEntity.name: Can I lead a normal life after spine surgery?

acceptedAnswer.text: Yes. The goal of surgery is to return you to a normal, active life. Most patients return to walking, driving, and even sports after the appropriate recovery period.

itemListElement.name: Clumsy Hands & Balance Issues? Identifying Cervical Myelopathy Symptoms

@graph.headline: Clumsy Hands & Balance Issues? Identifying Cervical Myelopathy Symptoms
@graph.description: Learn the warning signs of Cervical Myelopathy (Spinal Cord Compression). Understand why clumsy hands and balance issues require urgent neurosurgical attention.

mainEntity.name: Is cervical myelopathy reversible?

acceptedAnswer.text: Surgery can stop the progression of myelopathy and often leads to significant improvement, but long-standing spinal cord damage may not fully reverse. Early intervention is critical to prevent permanent loss of function.

mainEntity.name: How is myelopathy different from radiculopathy?

acceptedAnswer.text: Radiculopathy is the compression of a nerve root causing pain (like sciatica), while Myelopathy is the compression of the spinal cord itself, causing coordination and balance issues. Myelopathy is considered more urgent.

mainEntity.name: Can myelopathy be treated without surgery?

acceptedAnswer.text: Mild cases may be monitored, but since myelopathy is a progressive condition that threatens paralysis, surgery is often the primary treatment to decompress the spinal cord. Physical therapy cannot 'un-pinch' the spinal cord.

mainEntity.name: What is the best test for diagnosing myelopathy?

acceptedAnswer.text: An MRI of the cervical spine is the gold standard. It clearly shows the spinal cord compression and any signal changes (damage) within the cord that X-rays or CT scans might miss.

mainEntity.name: Can chiropractic adjustments help myelopathy?

acceptedAnswer.text: No. High-velocity neck manipulation is dangerous for patients with spinal cord compression and can lead to acute worsening or paralysis. Always consult a neurosurgeon first.

mainEntity.name: How long is the recovery after myelopathy surgery?

acceptedAnswer.text: Most patients stay in the hospital for 2-3 days. Walking begins immediately. Full bone fusion takes 3-6 months, but nerve recovery can continue for up to 18 months.

itemListElement.name: Is Spine Surgery Covered by Insurance in Hyderabad? (Cashless Guide)

@graph.headline: Is Spine Surgery Covered by Insurance in Hyderabad? (Cashless Guide)
@graph.description: Complete guide to spine surgery insurance coverage in Hyderabad. Check if your Mediclaim, Star Health, or corporate insurance covers endoscopic spine surgery.

mainEntity.name: Is endoscopic spine surgery covered by health insurance?

acceptedAnswer.text: Yes, endoscopic spine surgery is a standard medical procedure covered by almost all major insurance providers (Star, Apollo Munich, HDFC Ergo, etc.) and corporate group policies, provided the hospitalization exceeds 24 hours (which it usually does).

mainEntity.name: Is cashless facility available at Yashoda Hospital Malakpet?

acceptedAnswer.text: Yes, Yashoda Hospital Malakpet has tie-ups with all major TPAs and insurance companies for cashless claims. Our insurance desk handles the pre-authorization process.

mainEntity.name: Does CGHS or EHS cover spine surgery?

acceptedAnswer.text: Yes, government schemes like CGHS and EHS cover spine surgeries at empaneled hospitals. However, specific eligibility and room rent capping may apply.

mainEntity.name: What if my insurance claim is rejected?

acceptedAnswer.text: Rejections are rare for genuine medical necessities. If rejected, you can pay via cash/card and apply for reimbursement later. We assist with all necessary documentation.

mainEntity.name: Can I pay for surgery in EMIs?

acceptedAnswer.text: Yes, we facilitate 0% interest EMI options through third-party financial partners (like Bajaj Finserv) for eligible patients.

itemListElement.name: Spondylolisthesis Treatment Guide: Exercises, Bracing, and Surgery

@graph.headline: Spondylolisthesis Treatment Guide: Exercises, Bracing, and Surgery
@graph.description: A complete guide to treating Spondylolisthesis (slipped vertebra) in Hyderabad. Learn when exercises work, bracing helps, or fusion surgery is needed.

mainEntity.name: Can spondylolisthesis heal on its own?

acceptedAnswer.text: No, the slipped bone does not move back into place on its own. However, in many cases (especially Grade 1), symptoms can be completely managed with physical therapy and strengthening exercises, meaning you can live pain-free without surgery.

mainEntity.name: Is walking good for spondylolisthesis?

acceptedAnswer.text: Yes, walking is a low-impact exercise that helps maintain cardiovascular health without straining the back. However, if walking causes leg pain (claudication) due to nerve compression, you may need to rest frequently or consider treatment for spinal stenosis.

mainEntity.name: When is surgery absolutely necessary?

acceptedAnswer.text: Surgery is typically recommended if there is: 1) Progressive neurological weakness (foot drop), 2) Loss of bowel/bladder control, 3) High-grade slip (Grade 3 or 4), or 4) Severe pain that does not improve after 3-6 months of non-surgical treatment.

mainEntity.name: What is the success rate of spinal fusion for this condition?

acceptedAnswer.text: Spinal fusion for spondylolisthesis has a very high success rate, often over 90% for pain relief, because it directly addresses the mechanical instability causing the pain.

itemListElement.name: Failed Back Surgery Syndrome: Why Pain Persists & Treatment Options

@graph.headline: Failed Back Surgery Syndrome: Why Pain Persists & Treatment Options
@graph.description: Expert guide to Failed Back Surgery Syndrome (FBSS) in Hyderabad. Learn causes of recurrent pain and explore revision options like endoscopic spine surgery.

mainEntity.name: Why do I still have pain after back surgery?

acceptedAnswer.text: Pain can persist due to incomplete decompression, recurrent disc herniation, scar tissue formation (fibrosis), or spinal instability. It does not always mean the surgery was 'botched' but may require further evaluation.

mainEntity.name: What is the best treatment for Failed Back Surgery Syndrome?

acceptedAnswer.text: Treatment depends on the cause. Options range from medication and physical therapy to spinal injections and, in some cases, revision spine surgery using minimally invasive techniques.

mainEntity.name: Can scar tissue cause pain after spine surgery?

acceptedAnswer.text: Yes, epidural fibrosis (scar tissue) can trap nerves, causing recurrent pain. This is distinct from a new disc herniation and is diagnosed using MRI with contrast.

mainEntity.name: Is revision spine surgery dangerous?

acceptedAnswer.text: Revision surgery is more complex than primary surgery due to scar tissue. However, in expert hands using modern techniques like endoscopic surgery or neuromonitoring, risks are minimized.

itemListElement.name: What is Degenerative Disc Disease? Understanding 'Black Disc' and Spine Aging

@graph.headline: What is Degenerative Disc Disease? Understanding 'Black Disc' and Spine Aging
@graph.description: Learn about Degenerative Disc Disease (DDD), symptoms of black disc, and treatment options in Hyderabad. Understand when surgery is needed.

mainEntity.name: Can degenerative disc disease be reversed?

acceptedAnswer.text: No, once a disc has degenerated or dehydrated, it cannot 'regrow' or rehydrate to its original state. However, the symptoms can be managed effectively, and the spine can be stabilized to prevent pain.

mainEntity.name: Does a 'Black Disc' on my MRI mean I need surgery?

acceptedAnswer.text: Not necessarily. A 'black disc' simply indicates fluid loss. Many people have black discs with no pain at all. We treat the patient, not the MRI. Surgery is only considered if you have severe pain or nerve compression that doesn't improve with therapy.

mainEntity.name: Is walking good for degenerative disc disease?

acceptedAnswer.text: Yes, low-impact walking is excellent for DDD. It increases blood flow to the spine and strengthens the muscles supporting your back without placing excessive stress on the discs.

mainEntity.name: Will degenerative disc disease cause paralysis?

acceptedAnswer.text: It is extremely rare for DDD alone to cause paralysis. While it can cause pain and nerve compression (radiculopathy), it typically does not damage the spinal cord to the extent of causing paralysis unless there is severe canal stenosis or a massive herniation.

mainEntity.name: What is the best sleeping position for DDD?

acceptedAnswer.text: Sleeping on your back with a pillow under your knees, or on your side with a pillow between your legs, helps maintain neutral spine alignment and reduces stress on the discs.

itemListElement.name: Does Endoscopic Spine Surgery Work for Sciatica? (Hyderabad Guide)

@graph.headline: Does Endoscopic Spine Surgery Work for Sciatica? (Hyderabad Guide)
@graph.description: Does endoscopic spine surgery work for sciatica? Learn about its 90% success rate, same-day recovery, and safety benefits. Expert guide by Dr. Sayuj.

mainEntity.name: What is the success rate of endoscopic surgery for sciatica?

acceptedAnswer.text: Clinical studies and our own patient data show a success rate of over 90% for properly selected patients. Most patients experience immediate leg pain relief after the procedure.

mainEntity.name: Will my sciatica come back after surgery?

acceptedAnswer.text: The risk of recurrence (re-herniation) is low, typically around 3-5%. Maintaining a healthy weight and following our core strengthening protocol significantly reduces this risk.

mainEntity.name: How soon can I walk after endoscopic sciatica surgery?

acceptedAnswer.text: Almost immediately. We encourage patients to walk within 2-3 hours of the surgery. Most patients are discharged home on the same day or the next morning.

mainEntity.name: Is endoscopic surgery safer than open surgery?

acceptedAnswer.text: Yes. Because it uses a tiny 8mm incision and does not cut muscle or remove bone, there is significantly less blood loss, lower infection risk, and faster recovery compared to traditional open laminectomy.

itemListElement.name: Lumbar Spondylosis Treatment & Exercises: A Guide for Hyderabad Patients

@graph.headline: Lumbar Spondylosis Treatment & Exercises: A Guide for Hyderabad Patients
@graph.description: Comprehensive guide to Lumbar Spondylosis treatment in Hyderabad. Discover exercises, physiotherapy options, and when to see a spine specialist.

mainEntity.name: Can Lumbar Spondylosis be cured permanently?

acceptedAnswer.text: Spondylosis is an age-related condition (arthritis), so it cannot be 'reversed' completely. However, symptoms can be effectively managed, allowing for a pain-free life.

mainEntity.name: Is walking good for Lumbar Spondylosis?

acceptedAnswer.text: Yes, walking is a low-impact exercise that helps maintain spine flexibility and strengthens the muscles supporting your lower back.

mainEntity.name: What is the difference between Spondylosis and Spondylitis?

acceptedAnswer.text: Spondylosis is degenerative wear and tear (osteoarthritis). Spondylitis refers to inflammation of the vertebrae, often due to autoimmune conditions like Ankylosing Spondylitis.

mainEntity.name: When is surgery needed for Spondylosis?

acceptedAnswer.text: Surgery is rarely needed unless bone spurs or disc degeneration cause severe nerve compression (stenosis) leading to leg weakness or loss of bladder control.

itemListElement.name: Brain Aneurysm vs. Migraine: When a Headache is an Emergency

@graph.headline: Brain Aneurysm vs. Migraine: When a Headache is an Emergency
@graph.description: Worst headache of your life? It might be a brain aneurysm. Learn the difference between migraine and aneurysm symptoms and when to seek emergency care.

mainEntity.name: What does a brain aneurysm headache feel like?

acceptedAnswer.text: A ruptured brain aneurysm causes a 'thunderclap headache'—a sudden, blinding pain that reaches maximum intensity within seconds. Patients often describe it as the 'worst headache of their life.'

mainEntity.name: Can a migraine cause a brain aneurysm?

acceptedAnswer.text: No, migraines do not cause aneurysms. However, people with migraines can also have aneurysms. The key is to notice if your headache pattern changes drastically.

mainEntity.name: What is the main difference between migraine and aneurysm pain?

acceptedAnswer.text: Migraines usually build up gradually (minutes to hours) and throb. Aneurysm ruptures strike instantly like a physical blow to the head.

mainEntity.name: Is a brain aneurysm always fatal?

acceptedAnswer.text: Not always, but it is a medical emergency. Immediate treatment (clipping or coiling) significantly improves survival and recovery chances. Delaying care increases the risk of permanent damage.

mainEntity.name: Who is at risk for brain aneurysms?

acceptedAnswer.text: Risk factors include high blood pressure, smoking, family history, and age (over 40). Women are slightly more prone to aneurysms than men.

itemListElement.name: Cervical Disc Replacement vs. Fusion (ACDF): Which is Best for You?

@graph.headline: Cervical Disc Replacement vs. Fusion (ACDF): Which is Best for You?
@graph.description: Cervical Disc Replacement (ADR) vs ACDF Fusion: A neurosurgeon's guide to choosing the right neck surgery. Compare recovery, motion, and costs in Hyderabad.

mainEntity.name: Is cervical disc replacement safer than fusion?

acceptedAnswer.text: Both surgeries are extremely safe with success rates over 90%. Disc replacement avoids the risk of 'non-union' (bone not healing) but requires a surgeon skilled in the technique.

mainEntity.name: How long does an artificial disc last?

acceptedAnswer.text: Modern artificial discs are designed to last 40+ years. Lab testing suggests they can withstand decades of wear without failure.

mainEntity.name: Can I have disc replacement if I have arthritis?

acceptedAnswer.text: If you have significant arthritis in the facet joints (the small joints behind the disc), fusion is usually the better option, as movement in an arthritic joint causes pain.

mainEntity.name: What is the recovery time for ACDF vs. Disc Replacement?

acceptedAnswer.text: Disc replacement recovery is often faster (2-4 weeks for light work) because there is no need to wait for bone fusion. ACDF patients may need to wear a collar for 4-6 weeks.

mainEntity.name: Will I lose neck movement after fusion?

acceptedAnswer.text: A single-level fusion results in a very minor loss of motion that most patients don't notice. However, multi-level fusions can noticeably restrict neck stiffness.

itemListElement.name: Is It Dementia or a Brain Bleed? Chronic Subdural Hematoma in the Elderly

@graph.headline: Is It Dementia or a Brain Bleed? Chronic Subdural Hematoma in the Elderly
@graph.description: Chronic Subdural Hematoma (cSDH) in elderly: confusion, balance loss. Learn why this 'reversible dementia' needs urgent neurosurgery in Hyderabad.

mainEntity.name: Can a subdural hematoma heal on its own?

acceptedAnswer.text: Small, symptom-free hematomas might absorb over months with medication. However, if there is pressure on the brain causing confusion or weakness, surgery is usually required to prevent permanent damage.

mainEntity.name: Is burr hole surgery dangerous for a 80-year-old?

acceptedAnswer.text: Burr hole evacuation is one of the safest neurosurgical procedures. It is often done under local anesthesia or mild sedation, making it well-tolerated even by elderly patients with heart or BP issues.

mainEntity.name: How long after a fall can symptoms appear?

acceptedAnswer.text: Symptoms of Chronic Subdural Hematoma (cSDH) typically develop slowly over 2 to 6 weeks after a head injury. Sometimes the delay can be up to 3 months.

mainEntity.name: Will the memory loss improve after surgery?

acceptedAnswer.text: In most cases, yes. If the confusion was caused by the pressure of the blood clot, relieving that pressure often leads to a dramatic and rapid improvement in mental function.

itemListElement.name: Life After Spinal Fusion Surgery: Recovery and Mobility Truths in Hyderabad

@graph.headline: Life After Spinal Fusion Surgery: Recovery and Mobility Truths in Hyderabad
@graph.description: Discover life after spinal fusion surgery in Hyderabad. Learn about recovery timelines, mobility myths, and when you can drive or return to work.

mainEntity.name: Will I be able to bend after spinal fusion?

acceptedAnswer.text: Yes. While fusion eliminates motion at the operated level, your hips and remaining spine segments compensate. Most patients can bend, sit, and move normally after recovery.

mainEntity.name: When can I drive after spinal fusion surgery?

acceptedAnswer.text: Most patients can resume driving 4-6 weeks after surgery, once they are off pain medication and can react quickly without discomfort. Avoid driving on bumpy Hyderabad roads initially.

mainEntity.name: How long does it take for the bone to fuse completely?

acceptedAnswer.text: It typically takes 3 to 6 months for the bone graft to fuse solid with the vertebrae. However, you will feel significant pain relief much sooner.

mainEntity.name: Can I return to gym or sports after fusion?

acceptedAnswer.text: Low-impact activities like walking and swimming are encouraged early. Heavy lifting and contact sports are usually restricted for 6-12 months to ensure solid fusion.

itemListElement.name: How to Sleep with Sciatica: Best Positions for Pain Relief

@graph.headline: How to Sleep with Sciatica: Best Positions for Pain Relief
@graph.description: Struggling to sleep with sciatica? Learn the best sleeping positions to relieve nerve pain, choose the right mattress, and wake up pain-free in Hyderabad.

mainEntity.name: Why is my sciatica worse at night?

acceptedAnswer.text: Lying down can increase pressure on the disc or nerve depending on your position. Also, inflammatory chemicals that accumulate during the day can pool around the nerve roots at night.

mainEntity.name: Is a hard or soft mattress better for sciatica?

acceptedAnswer.text: A medium-firm mattress is generally best. It provides enough support to keep the spine aligned while offering enough cushion for the hips and shoulders.

mainEntity.name: Can I sleep on the floor with sciatica?

acceptedAnswer.text: For some patients, sleeping on a firm surface like the floor with a mat helps keep the spine neutral. However, for others, it may be too hard on pressure points. Listen to your body.

mainEntity.name: How should I get out of bed with back pain?

acceptedAnswer.text: Use the 'log roll' method: turn onto your side, drop your legs off the edge of the bed, and push yourself up with your arms, keeping your spine straight.

mainEntity.name: Does a pillow between the knees help?

acceptedAnswer.text: Yes, placing a pillow between your knees when sleeping on your side keeps your hips aligned and prevents the top leg from pulling your spine out of alignment.

itemListElement.name: Types of Spine Tumors: Benign vs. Cancerous & Warning Signs

@graph.headline: Types of Spine Tumors: Benign vs. Cancerous & Warning Signs
@graph.description: Dr. Sayuj Krishnan explains spinal tumors: types (benign vs. cancerous), red flag symptoms, and treatment options available in Hyderabad.

mainEntity.name: Is back pain a common sign of a spine tumor?

acceptedAnswer.text: Back pain is the most common early symptom of a spine tumor, but it is also the most common symptom of many non-serious conditions (like muscle strain). Pain from a tumor is often different: it may worsen at night, isn't relieved by rest, and may radiate to the arms or legs.

mainEntity.name: What is the difference between a primary and secondary spine tumor?

acceptedAnswer.text: A primary spine tumor originates in the spine itself (bones, nerves, or spinal cord). A secondary (metastatic) tumor spreads to the spine from cancer elsewhere in the body, such as the lung, breast, or prostate. Secondary tumors are much more common.

mainEntity.name: Are all spine tumors cancerous?

acceptedAnswer.text: No. Many primary spine tumors, such as meningiomas and schwannomas, are benign (non-cancerous). They grow slowly but can still cause problems by pressing on the spinal cord or nerves.

mainEntity.name: How are spine tumors diagnosed?

acceptedAnswer.text: The gold standard for diagnosis is an MRI scan, which shows the spinal cord and soft tissues in detail. CT scans may be used to assess bone involvement. A biopsy is often required to confirm the exact type of tumor.

mainEntity.name: Can spine tumors be cured?

acceptedAnswer.text: Benign tumors can often be completely removed and cured with surgery. For malignant (cancerous) tumors, treatment focuses on removing as much of the tumor as safely as possible (decompression), stabilizing the spine, and using radiation or chemotherapy to control growth and relieve pain.

itemListElement.name: Epilepsy Surgery: When Medications Stop Working (A Patient's Guide)

@graph.headline: Epilepsy Surgery: When Medications Stop Working (A Patient's Guide)
@graph.description: Comprehensive guide to epilepsy surgery options in Hyderabad for drug-resistant seizures. Learn about VNS, LITT, and resection surgery for seizure freedom.

mainEntity.name: When should I consider surgery for epilepsy?

acceptedAnswer.text: If you have tried two or more anti-epileptic medications at the correct dose without seizure control, you may have 'drug-resistant epilepsy' and should be evaluated for surgical options.

mainEntity.name: Is epilepsy surgery dangerous?

acceptedAnswer.text: All brain surgeries carry risk, but with modern neuronavigation and monitoring, the risks are often lower than the cumulative risk of uncontrolled seizures over a lifetime.

mainEntity.name: What is the success rate of epilepsy surgery?

acceptedAnswer.text: Success depends on the type of epilepsy. For well-selected candidates with a clear focus (like temporal lobe epilepsy), seizure freedom rates can be 60-80%.

mainEntity.name: What is VNS therapy?

acceptedAnswer.text: Vagus Nerve Stimulation (VNS) is like a 'pacemaker for the brain.' It involves a small device implanted under the skin that sends signals to the brain to prevent seizures.

mainEntity.name: How long is the recovery after epilepsy surgery?

acceptedAnswer.text: Hospital stay is typically 3-5 days. Most patients return to normal activities within 4-6 weeks, though driving restrictions depend on seizure freedom.

itemListElement.name: Cervical Radiculopathy: Why Your Neck Pain Shoots Down Your Arm

@graph.headline: Cervical Radiculopathy: Why Your Neck Pain Shoots Down Your Arm
@graph.description: Dr. Sayuj Krishnan explains Cervical Radiculopathy (pinched nerve): causes, symptoms like arm numbness, and advanced treatments in Hyderabad.

mainEntity.name: How do I know if my arm pain is from my neck?

acceptedAnswer.text: If your arm pain is accompanied by neck stiffness, worsens when you turn your head, or feels like an electric shock traveling down the arm, it is likely cervical radiculopathy. Pain that is relieved by lifting your hand above your head (Shoulder Abduction Sign) is also a strong indicator.

mainEntity.name: Will a pinched nerve heal on its own?

acceptedAnswer.text: Yes, in many cases. About 70-80% of patients with cervical radiculopathy improve with conservative treatments like rest, physiotherapy, and medication within 6 to 8 weeks. Surgery is usually only considered if these fail or if there is significant weakness.

mainEntity.name: Is cervical radiculopathy the same as a heart attack?

acceptedAnswer.text: Left arm pain can be a sign of a heart attack, but heart attack pain is often accompanied by chest pressure, sweating, and shortness of breath. Radiculopathy pain is usually sharp, electrical, and specific to certain fingers or areas of the arm, often triggered by neck movement. Always seek emergency care if you are unsure.

mainEntity.name: Can physiotherapy cure a pinched nerve?

acceptedAnswer.text: Physiotherapy is highly effective. Techniques like cervical traction, posture correction, and strengthening exercises can relieve pressure on the nerve root, allowing inflammation to subside and symptoms to resolve.

mainEntity.name: When is surgery needed for a pinched nerve?

acceptedAnswer.text: Surgery is recommended if you have progressive muscle weakness (e.g., dropping objects), loss of sensation, unbearable pain that doesn't improve with medication, or signs of spinal cord compression (myelopathy) like balance issues.

itemListElement.name: Meningioma Brain Tumor: When is Surgery Needed vs. Observation?

@graph.headline: Meningioma Brain Tumor: When is Surgery Needed vs. Observation?
@graph.description: Meningioma treatment guide by Dr. Sayuj Krishnan. Learn about 'wait and watch' vs surgery, symptoms, and benign brain tumor recovery in Hyderabad.

mainEntity.name: Is a meningioma a type of brain cancer?

acceptedAnswer.text: No. More than 90% of meningiomas are Grade I (benign). They grow slowly and do not spread to other parts of the body. However, even benign tumors can be dangerous if they press on the brain or nerves.

mainEntity.name: Can a meningioma stop growing?

acceptedAnswer.text: Some meningiomas grow very slowly or calcify and stop growing naturally. This is why 'wait and watch' with regular MRI scans is often the first line of management for small, asymptomatic tumors in older patients.

mainEntity.name: How long is the recovery after meningioma surgery?

acceptedAnswer.text: Most patients are discharged in 3-4 days. You can walk the next day. Full recovery and return to normal activities typically takes 4-6 weeks, depending on the tumor's location.

mainEntity.name: Is Gamma Knife better than surgery for meningioma?

acceptedAnswer.text: Gamma Knife (Radiosurgery) is excellent for small tumors (<3cm) that are hard to reach or for patients unfit for open surgery. However, large tumors causing pressure symptoms usually require surgical removal first.

mainEntity.name: What are the warning signs that a meningioma is growing?

acceptedAnswer.text: New or worsening headaches, vision changes (blurriness/double vision), seizures, weakness in an arm or leg, or personality changes suggest the tumor is exerting pressure and may need treatment.

itemListElement.name: L4-L5 Disc Bulge: Symptoms, Risks, and Treatment Options in Hyderabad

@graph.headline: L4-L5 Disc Bulge: Symptoms, Risks, and Treatment Options in Hyderabad
@graph.description: L4-L5 disc bulge guide by Dr. Sayuj Krishnan. Learn about symptoms like sciatica, foot drop red flags, and non-surgical treatments in Hyderabad.

mainEntity.name: Can an L4-L5 disc bulge heal on its own?

acceptedAnswer.text: Yes, in about 90% of cases, the bulging portion of the disc shrinks or dries up (resorption) over 6-12 weeks with proper rest, medication, and physiotherapy.

mainEntity.name: What are the symptoms of L4-L5 nerve compression?

acceptedAnswer.text: Common symptoms include lower back pain, pain radiating down the side of the thigh and calf to the big toe (sciatica), and numbness or tingling in the foot.

mainEntity.name: Is walking good for L4-L5 disc bulge?

acceptedAnswer.text: Short, frequent walks are generally beneficial as they improve blood flow. However, avoid long walks or uneven surfaces if they increase your pain.

mainEntity.name: When is surgery required for L4-L5 slip disc?

acceptedAnswer.text: Surgery is typically recommended only if there is 'foot drop' (weakness), loss of bladder control, or if unbearable pain persists despite 6 weeks of non-surgical treatment.

itemListElement.name: 5 Sciatica Exercises for Office Workers in Hyderabad

@graph.headline: 5 Sciatica Exercises for Office Workers in Hyderabad
@graph.description: Best sciatica exercises for software engineers and office workers in Hyderabad. Learn how to prevent back pain from long sitting hours with Dr. Sayuj Krishnan.

mainEntity.name: Can sitting too long cause sciatica?

acceptedAnswer.text: Yes, prolonged sitting compresses the lumbar discs and tightens the piriformis muscle, both of which can irritate the sciatic nerve.

mainEntity.name: How often should I do these exercises?

acceptedAnswer.text: Aim for short 'micro-breaks' every hour. Doing these stretches for 2 minutes every hour is better than a 30-minute session once a day.

mainEntity.name: Do I need a standing desk?

acceptedAnswer.text: A standing desk helps, but it's not a cure-all. Alternating between sitting and standing every 45 minutes is the most effective strategy.

mainEntity.name: When should I see a doctor?

acceptedAnswer.text: If you have numbness, weakness in the leg, or pain that doesn't improve with these exercises after 2 weeks, consult a spine specialist.

itemListElement.name: Spinal Tuberculosis (Pott's Spine) Symptoms & Treatment: A Guide for Hyderabad Patients

@graph.headline: Spinal Tuberculosis (Pott's Spine) Symptoms & Treatment: A Guide for Hyderabad Patients
@graph.description: Learn about Spinal Tuberculosis (Pott's Spine) symptoms, diagnosis, and treatment in Hyderabad. Understand when medication works and when surgery is needed.

mainEntity.name: Is spinal tuberculosis curable?

acceptedAnswer.text: Yes, spinal tuberculosis is completely curable with a strict course of anti-tubercular medication (ATT), typically lasting 12 to 18 months.

mainEntity.name: Does spinal TB always require surgery?

acceptedAnswer.text: No. 80-90% of patients recover with medication alone. Surgery is only needed if there is severe nerve compression, instability, or large abscesses.

mainEntity.name: Is spinal TB contagious?

acceptedAnswer.text: Spinal TB itself is usually not contagious unless the patient also has active pulmonary (lung) tuberculosis. A chest X-ray helps rule this out.

mainEntity.name: What are the first signs of Pott's spine?

acceptedAnswer.text: Persistent back pain that worsens at night, low-grade fever, unexplained weight loss, and fatigue are early warning signs.

itemListElement.name: Normal Pressure Hydrocephalus (NPH): The "Reversible Dementia" You Should Know

@graph.headline: Normal Pressure Hydrocephalus (NPH): The "Reversible Dementia" You Should Know
@graph.description: A guide to Normal Pressure Hydrocephalus (NPH) symptoms and treatment in Hyderabad. Learn how VP Shunt surgery can reverse dementia-like symptoms.

mainEntity.name: How is NPH different from Alzheimer's?

acceptedAnswer.text: While both cause memory loss, NPH has a distinct 'triad' of symptoms: walking difficulty (shuffling gait), urinary incontinence, and memory issues. In Alzheimer's, memory loss is usually the first and most dominant symptom, while in NPH, walking difficulty often appears first.

mainEntity.name: Is NPH curable?

acceptedAnswer.text: NPH is often called 'reversible dementia' because the symptoms can be significantly improved with surgical treatment (VP Shunt). Unlike Alzheimer's or Parkinson's, which are progressive and degenerative, treating the fluid buildup in NPH can restore function.

mainEntity.name: What is a VP Shunt?

acceptedAnswer.text: A Ventriculoperitoneal (VP) Shunt is a thin tube implanted under the skin. It drains excess cerebrospinal fluid from the brain into the abdomen, where it is naturally absorbed. It acts as a safety valve to keep brain pressure normal.

mainEntity.name: Is the surgery safe for elderly patients?

acceptedAnswer.text: Yes, VP shunt surgery is a common and relatively safe procedure performed frequently on patients over 60, 70, or even 80. The risk of untreated NPH (falls, complete immobility) is often much higher than the surgical risk.

mainEntity.name: How long is the recovery after shunt surgery?

acceptedAnswer.text: Most patients stay in the hospital for 2-3 days. Improvement in walking can sometimes be seen within days, while memory and bladder control may take weeks or months to improve gradually.

itemListElement.name: Sciatica Pain Relief Exercises at Home: A Guide for Hyderabad Patients

@graph.headline: Sciatica Pain Relief Exercises at Home: A Guide for Hyderabad Patients
@graph.description: Discover the best sciatica pain relief exercises at home. Learn safe stretches, posture tips, and when to see a spine specialist in Hyderabad.

mainEntity.name: Can walking help with sciatica?

acceptedAnswer.text: Yes, gentle walking is good for sciatica as it improves blood flow and reduces inflammation. However, avoid long walks if they aggravate pain.

mainEntity.name: Which exercises should I avoid with sciatica?

acceptedAnswer.text: Avoid heavy lifting, deep squats, and double leg lifts. These put excessive pressure on the lumbar discs and can worsen nerve compression.

mainEntity.name: Is heat or ice better for sciatica?

acceptedAnswer.text: Ice is better for acute pain (first 48 hours) to reduce inflammation. Heat is better for chronic stiffness and muscle relaxation.

mainEntity.name: How long does it take for sciatica to heal with exercises?

acceptedAnswer.text: Most patients see improvement within 4-6 weeks of consistent exercises. If pain persists, consult a spine specialist.

itemListElement.name: Awake Craniotomy: Why and How Brain Surgery Is Performed While You Are Awake

@graph.headline: Awake Craniotomy: Why and How Brain Surgery Is Performed While You Are Awake
@graph.description: Dr. Sayuj Krishnan explains Awake Craniotomy: a technique for removing brain tumors near critical areas while preserving speech and motor function.

mainEntity.name: Is awake brain surgery painful?

acceptedAnswer.text: No. The brain itself has no pain receptors, so you cannot feel the surgeon touching or removing tissue. The scalp and skull are numbed with local anesthesia (blocks) before the surgery begins to ensure you remain comfortable.

mainEntity.name: Will I be awake for the entire surgery?

acceptedAnswer.text: Usually, no. Most surgeons use an 'Asleep-Awake-Asleep' protocol. You are under general anesthesia for the opening (incision) and closing steps. You are only woken up during the critical middle part of the surgery for mapping and tumor removal.

mainEntity.name: What if I panic or move during the surgery?

acceptedAnswer.text: This is a common fear, but the surgical team prepares you extensively beforehand. During the procedure, your head is securely fixed in a frame so you cannot move it accidentally. An anesthesiologist is right next to you the entire time to manage anxiety and keep you calm.

mainEntity.name: How long does an awake craniotomy take?

acceptedAnswer.text: The duration varies depending on the tumor's complexity, but the surgery typically lasts between 3 to 5 hours. The 'awake' portion may only last 45 minutes to an hour.

mainEntity.name: What are the benefits of awake craniotomy?

acceptedAnswer.text: The primary benefit is safety. It allows the surgeon to maximize tumor removal while minimizing the risk of permanent damage to speech, language, or movement. It often leads to shorter hospital stays and faster recovery since less general anesthesia is used.

itemListElement.name: Cauda Equina Syndrome: The Back Pain Emergency You Cannot Ignore

@graph.headline: Cauda Equina Syndrome: The Back Pain Emergency You Cannot Ignore
@graph.description: Cauda Equina Syndrome is a surgical emergency. If you have saddle numbness or bladder loss with back pain, seek help in Hyderabad immediately.

mainEntity.name: What is the first sign of Cauda Equina Syndrome?

acceptedAnswer.text: Often it starts with severe back pain and sciatica in both legs, followed quickly by numbness in the groin area ('saddle anesthesia') and difficulty urinating.

mainEntity.name: Can Cauda Equina Syndrome cure itself?

acceptedAnswer.text: No. It is a mechanical compression of nerves that requires urgent surgical decompression. Delaying treatment can lead to permanent paralysis or incontinence.

mainEntity.name: How much time do I have to operate?

acceptedAnswer.text: The 'golden window' is typically within 24 to 48 hours of the onset of bladder/bowel symptoms. Surgery within this timeframe offers the best chance of recovery.

mainEntity.name: Is Cauda Equina Syndrome painful?

acceptedAnswer.text: Yes, usually there is severe low back pain. However, the most dangerous symptom is actually the *lack* of feeling (numbness) in the saddle area.

mainEntity.name: Can a slip disc cause Cauda Equina Syndrome?

acceptedAnswer.text: Yes, a massive central disc herniation is the most common cause. It fills the spinal canal and crushes the entire bundle of nerves at the end of the spinal cord.

itemListElement.name: Slipped Disc vs. Slipped Vertebra (Spondylolisthesis): Understanding the Difference

@graph.headline: Slipped Disc vs. Slipped Vertebra (Spondylolisthesis): Understanding the Difference
@graph.description: Spondylolisthesis vs herniated disc: symptoms, imaging clues, and when stabilization or simple decompression is needed.

mainEntity.name: Can spondylolisthesis be cured without surgery?

acceptedAnswer.text: Yes, low-grade slips (Grade I) often respond well to core strengthening exercises and physiotherapy to stabilize the spine naturally. Surgery is only needed if there is severe nerve compression or the slip is progressing.

mainEntity.name: Does a herniated disc always lead to spondylolisthesis?

acceptedAnswer.text: No. A herniated disc is an issue with the cushion between bones. Spondylolisthesis is an issue with the alignment of the bones themselves. While disc degeneration can contribute to instability, they are distinct conditions.

mainEntity.name: Is walking good for spondylolisthesis?

acceptedAnswer.text: Generally, yes, but listen to your body. Some patients with spondylolisthesis have 'neurogenic claudication,' where walking causes leg heaviness. In such cases, leaning forward (like on a shopping cart) or cycling might be more comfortable.

mainEntity.name: Do I need screws (fusion) for a slipped disc?

acceptedAnswer.text: Rarely. A simple slipped disc usually requires only a microdiscectomy or endoscopic discectomy to remove the pressure. Screws (fusion) are typically reserved for spondylolisthesis where the spine is unstable.

mainEntity.name: What is the recovery time for spondylolisthesis surgery?

acceptedAnswer.text: If fusion is required, recovery takes a bit longer than a simple discectomy. Patients are usually walking the same day but need 6-12 weeks for the bone to heal fully. Minimally invasive TLIF reduces this recovery time significantly.
